description: Inherited from Middle English credulite (“faith, belief”), borrowed from Middle French credulité (French crédulité), from Latin crēdulitās. Corresponding to credulous +‎ -ity (compare credulosity).

entries.meaning: A willingness to believe in someone or something in the absence of reasonable proof; credulousness.
(now nonstandard) Faith, credence; acceptance or maintenance of a belief.
